articles.title: MAY 1985
articles.summary: This document details a schedule of astronomical events for May and early June 1985, primarily for an astronomy club. Key activities include the 8th Annual Astronomical Auction, pre-auction planning, and two field expeditions for astronomical observation. Other events feature the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference, a general meeting with a guest speaker on observing and amateur astronomy, and an indoor star party.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION
articles.summary: This article announces two significant astronomical events: an Astronomical Auction on May 11th at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, urging attendees to bring items for sale and pre-register. It also details the 17th Annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference (RTMC) from May 24-27th at Camp Oakes near Big Bear City, highlighting its suitability for deep-sky observing and its status as a major gathering for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article details a weekend observing session at Fremont Peak around March 23rd, characterized by clear skies but high humidity, which caused issues for Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope owners. Despite challenging conditions, attendees enjoyed activities like a demonstration of the new Minolta Maxxum SLR camera and filming for the future P.P.O. "A" observatory. Observations of objects like "The Ring Tail" galaxy and M81 were made, and preparations were noted for the movement of John Stewart's large observatory dome.

articles.title: COMET MAINIA STRIKES TELESCOPE MANUFACTURES
articles.summary: The article observes that telescope prices, particularly for 8" Celestron C8 models, have significantly increased, noting a $2400 list price in the Spring Orion Telescope Center catalogue. This surge is attributed to a "Comet Halley mania" driving up demand, with the author predicting a substantial price drop by the end of 1986 once the comet is no longer visible.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWALS
articles.summary: SJAA members are advised to send their Sky and Telescope subscription renewal cards and membership renewals to Bob Fingerhut. Submitting renewals promptly will ensure uninterrupted delivery of Sky and Telescope magazine and the Ephemeris.

articles.title: YOSEMITE STAR PARTY
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association is planning a star party in Yosemite National Park on July 12/13, with camping at Bridalveil campground and observing at Glacier Point. Attendees are required to entertain park guests with their telescopes until late evening, and coordination with the event organizer is necessary for sign-up and specific details regarding power and telescope setup.

articles.title: EQUIPMENT
articles.summary: The article reviews J.M.I. Inc.'s electric focuser, a device that attaches to Celestron or Meade telescopes, enabling remote focus adjustments with a 5-digit position display. While it significantly eases critical focusing for astrophotography, the unit's motor can cause telescope shake and interfere with off-axis guiders and multiple eyepiece holders, requiring an extension tube. Despite these issues, the author highly recommends it for serious astrophotographers seeking an electrically focusable telescope.

articles.title: FPOA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: The SJAA board has approved the inclusion of the FPOA membership application form in the Ephemeris publication. This informs members and interested parties about the availability of the application.

articles.title: VOJVODICH SPEAKS TO THE SJAA
articles.summary: Nick Vojvodich, Project Manager for the Galileo Jupiter orbiter, presented to 30 members of the SJAA, providing an informative mission description despite technical difficulties. He announced a NASA update, adding an asteroid option to the Galileo mission and changing Jupiter's arrival date to December 10, 1988. The mission's 22-month tour will focus on long-term studies of Io's active volcanoes, Jupiter's atmosphere, and high-resolution mapping of its satellites.

articles.title: LUNAR SILHOUETTES
articles.summary: The SJAA thanked Bob Hewett and Dick Humpheries for attending an Indoor Star Party and wished them luck with their project to photograph the full Moon rising behind Mt. Hamilton observatory buildings. Additionally, the article announces an upcoming June 1st General Meeting where Jay Fregman will present on amateur astronomy observing, covering telescope types, eyepieces, and techniques, which is highly recommended for beginners.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz's "Comet Comments" for 1985 reports the recovery of Periodic Comet Ashbrook-Jackson (1985a1) on March 20 at magnitude 18, with expectations to brighten to magnitude 13 by late summer. It also provides an ephemeris and observational notes for Comet Shoemaker (1984f), noting its southern location, fainter-than-expected magnitude 11.3, and diffuse appearance. The article briefly mentions Comet Halley's position and historical comet observations.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND - HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: The article discusses the current (at the time of writing) and anticipated visibility of Halley's Comet, noting its faintness compared to its spectacular 1910 appearance. It elaborates on Halley's 1910 pass and introduces "The Great January Comet" of the same year, a brighter but unexpected comet that many might have confused with Halley's, detailing key differences in their visibility and characteristics. The author suggests most people likely saw Halley's, despite the other comet's brightness.

articles.title: DATE(1985) R.A. (1950) DEC ELONG SKY MAG. DIS. SUN AND EARTH
articles.summary: This document presents an ephemeris for Halley's Comet (1910 II) for select dates between April and June 1985. It provides crucial astronomical data including right ascension, declination, elongation, sky visibility (morning/evening), visual magnitude, and its distances from both the Sun and Earth. This information is vital for observers tracking the comet's position and brightness during that period.

articles.title: DATE(1910) R.A. (1950) DEC ELONG SKY MAG. DIS. SUN AND EARTH
articles.summary: The article presents an ephemeris for 'The Great January Comet (1910 I)', detailing its observational data across several dates in January and early February 1910. It includes specific figures for Right Ascension, Declination, sky elongation (morning/evening), visual magnitude, and distances from both the Sun and Earth. The data indicates the comet reached its peak brightness around January 20th, observed in the evening sky.

articles.title: REFRESHMENTS WANTED
articles.summary: The SVAA is requesting members to bring food and beverages to this year's auction, replicating last year's successful refreshment contribution. Members are encouraged to bring extra items like hot dogs, chips, dips, and soft drinks to share with others attending the event.

articles.title: BY: STEVE GOTTLIEB
articles.summary: The article presents Steve Gottlieb's detailed observational notes on challenging and often misidentified planetary nebulae, including Abell 31, Minkowski 1-18, Kohodsandulak 2-21, and PK 164+31 1, complete with historical cataloging errors and observing specifics. Additionally, Don Machholz provides a guide for observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot, offering practical advice on required magnification, techniques, and a schedule for optimal viewing in 1985.

articles.title: DISCOVERY LAUNCHED APRIL 12TH
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Discovery launched on April 12th, deploying a Canadian Telesat satellite. However, the satellite was crippled by a lack of power, preventing its rocket from functioning. A subsequent spacewalk successfully attempted a repair, but the satellite still failed to activate when handled by the shuttle's remote manipulator arm.

articles.title: CHALLENGER SCHEDULED FOR LAUNCH APRIL 29TH
articles.summary: The Spacelab 3, mission 51-B, aboard the Challenger space shuttle is scheduled for launch in the period of April 14 or 15. The mission aims to conduct various experiments, including those in material science and fluid mechanics, and will also carry instruments for astronomical observations.

articles.title: NEW SHUTTLE MANIFEST ISSUED
articles.summary: The article announces the revised Space Shuttle manifest for the remainder of the year and into early 1986, detailing several missions with their scheduled dates, assigned orbiters (Discovery, Challenger, Atlantis, Columbia), and primary payloads. Key missions include Spacelab deployments, communication satellite launches, material science labs, and a Department of Defense mission. It also mentions the delivery of Atlantis to KSC and the delay of the first Vandenberg flight to March 1986.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT RECOVERED!
articles.summary: The Great Red Spot of Jupiter was successfully observed on April 14 at Fremont Peak state park under excellent conditions, noting its yellow color, position on the southern equatorial belt, and a new, strangely oval shape. The article details the observation and provides practical tips for amateur astronomers to view the Spot, including recommended equipment and optimal viewing times, emphasizing the need for good seeing and sufficient magnification.

articles.title: ARIANE LAUNCH DELAYED
articles.summary: The Ariane launch, initially planned for April 23, has been postponed until May 7 due to concerns about possible contamination of the rocket's components. This mission is intended to deploy two communication satellites: GTE Spacenet from the USA and France's Telecom-1B.

articles.title: NASA AND JAPAN AGREE ON SPACELAB FLIGHT
articles.summary: NASA and Japan have reached an agreement for a Spacelab flight in January 1988. During this mission, a Japanese astronaut will perform approximately 34 different materials processing tests, marking Japan's first such experiment.

articles.title: NASA TESTING GRAZING INCIDENCE MIRRORS
articles.summary: NASA is conducting tests on grazing incidence mirrors at an X-ray test facility at MSFC. These mirrors are crucial for short wavelength astronomy and are intended for the Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility (AXAF), which NASA aims to initiate in fiscal year 1987. A minimum angular resolution has been established for these tests to meet AXAF's requirements.

articles.title: GALILEO COMPLETES INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL TESTS
articles.summary: The Galileo spacecraft has successfully completed its initial environmental tests. It is now scheduled for shipment from JPL in December, with its launch anticipated in May 1986.

articles.title: ESA DEFINES SATURN MOON PROBE
articles.summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) has finished preliminary definition work for a descent probe designed for Titan, Saturn's largest moon. This probe is intended to be part of NASA's proposed Cassini mission to Saturn, which was planned for the 1990s.

articles.title: AGREEMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION ON SPACE STATION REACHED
articles.summary: NASA has finalized an agreement with Europe, Japan, and Canada for international cooperation on the space station, enabling Phase B definition studies to commence. Europe's contribution includes a Man Tended Free Flying platform, part of its Columbus program, while NASA has also selected six U.S. contractor teams for design work. A specific award for the overall station structure has been postponed due to intense competition.

articles.title: USSR REVEALS SPACE PLANS
articles.summary: Russian scientists visiting the U.S. revealed detailed plans for future Soviet space missions. These include a 1986 Mars/Phobos mission involving two spacecraft, one to study Phobos up close with laser and ion beams; a 1989-90 Lunar Polar Orbiter for geochemical mapping; and a proposed 1991 Venus/Asteroid lander mission, which is not yet approved.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document features two classified advertisements related to astronomical equipment. One ad offers a large 22" Burk tube with mirrors for free, while the other is a 'wanted' ad for a Convert Compact 10" f/5 Dobsonian telescope.

articles.title: SPRING STAR PARTY AT THE PEAK BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article details a highly successful Spring Star Party at Fremont Peak on April 13th, marked by unusually warm weather and excellent observing conditions. Attendees enjoyed spectacular celestial views, including the 'first light' of Bob Fingerhut's new 18-inch telescope, which offered phenomenal sights of the Eagle and Horsehead Nebulae. Observers also reported impressive observations of Saturn, Jupiter, and a particularly vivid view of the Trifid Nebula, making it one of the finest spring star parties held at the location.

articles.title: QUESTIONS OF THE MONTH
articles.summary: This article, titled 'QUESTIONS OF THE MONTH', serves as an internal inquiry from the club regarding the whereabouts of its $1000 CID camera and several club telescopes. It specifically mentions that David O. York currently has the club's 14-inch telescope and is looking for someone to take responsibility for it. The club requests members to contact the editor or David O. York with information or to arrange a transfer of the telescope.

articles.title: GUIDELINES FOR PARTICIPATION IN GLACIER POINT STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: This document details the operational guidelines for participating in Glacier Point Star Parties, issued by the park service. It outlines rules for vehicle limits, participant numbers, telescope setup locations, camping regulations at both Glacier Point Ranger Station and Bridalveil Campground, and the primary goal of providing an astronomy interpretive program for park visitors. An editor's note offers additional advice on site benefits and astrophotography opportunities.

articles.title: SATURDAY MAY 11TH 6:00 PM
articles.summary: This document announces a major astronomical swap meet and sale event scheduled for Saturday, May 11th, at 6:00 PM (doors open at 2:00 PM) at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. It's an opportunity for individuals to buy and sell a wide array of astronomical equipment and related items, from telescopes and eyepieces to books and space art, and is described as one of the biggest and most fun astronomical events in the Bay Area.

articles.title: PRE-REGISTRATION INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document outlines the pre-registration process for the 5th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, an event where individuals can sell astronomy or telescope-making related items. Participants are instructed to fill out a form, list their items with minimum prices and a percentage for the SJAA, and mail it with a Self-Addressed Stamped Envelope (SASE) to receive their bidder and item numbers prior to the event. The article also provides directions to the auction location, outlines the day's schedule including item registration cutoff times and auction start, payment methods, and a bidder/seller registration fee, with all proceeds benefiting public education in astronomy.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK OBSERVATORY ASSOCIATION
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA), founded in 1981 by Bay Area amateur astronomers, aims to build and operate an observatory at Fremont Peak State Park in California. This non-profit organization is planning to house 30-inch and 22-inch telescopes for public programs and private use, with completion expected in late 1985. The FPOA is currently seeking $8,000 in contributions and new members to fund construction and viewing opportunities, particularly anticipating Halley's Comet.

articles.title: All classes of membership are entitled to the following privileges:
articles.summary: This document details the privileges and rules for membership in the Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA). Members are entitled to use telescopes and facilities, receive a quarterly newsletter, and participate in public viewing events, with voting rights generally activated after one year for non-corporate members. It also outlines a one-time initiation fee, the tax-deductible nature of contributions, and specific provisions for "Charter Members" through December 1985, along with payment instructions.

articles.title: Application For Membership
articles.summary: This document is an application form for membership in the Fremont Peak Observatory Association. It details various membership categories (General, Family, Contributing, Sustaining, Life, Corporate) along with their annual fees and a one-time initiation fee. Applicants are prompted to provide personal information, select a membership category, and submit payment.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document provides details for the monthly general meetings of the SJAA, which are held at 8 PM at the Los Gatos Red Cross building. This location, 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., Los Gatos, California, also hosts the SJAA's indoor star parties. Detailed driving directions from Hwy 17 are included for attendees.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is introduced as a new observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road, halfway between San Jose and Lick Observatory. The article provides directions to the park and instructions for after-sunset access, including a combination lock (4585) for the gate and the importance of relocking it.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, advising visitors to take the East Dunne exit from Hwy 101 and continue east to the park. It includes specific instructions for arrival, such as how to handle the gate (which is left open for SJAA members to close) and a tip to park outside and hike in first if arriving after dark to find an observing site, using only parking lights once inside.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving instructions to Fremont Peak State Park, which serves as a site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It includes turn-by-turn directions from Hollister or San Juan Bautista and a reminder about parking light usage after dark. The article also briefly mentions "EPHEMERIS," a monthly publication by the SJAA.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the officers of an organization, including the President (Robert Fingerhut), Vice-President (Dave Ambrose), Secretary (James Van Nuland), and Treasurer (Robert Fingerhut). It provides their names, titles, addresses, and phone numbers.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the names and corresponding phone numbers of the members of an organization's Board of Directors. It serves as a contact roster for individuals such as Paul Mancuso, Steve Greenberg, Tom Ahl, and others.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association) offers three telescopes for members to borrow for two-month periods. Members are responsible for arranging the transfer of telescopes among themselves and notifying a board member or editor when a telescope changes hands. Additionally, the article mentions that members and friends can place astronomical-related want ads in the Ephemeris publication, which will run for two months unless otherwise specified.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines various membership options, including standard adult, junior (under 18), and a combined membership with a Sky & Telescope magazine subscription, each with its corresponding fee. The form also provides instructions for submission, either by bringing it to an SJAA meeting or mailing it to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information from individuals about their astronomical interests, such as astro-photography or deep-sky observation, and whether they own a telescope. It also asks if they have expertise in any area of astronomy that could be shared with others. The inclusion of mailing information for "SJAA EPHEMERIS" suggests it's part of a publication from an astronomy club or organization.
